Article.ArticleTitle: Mesophyll conductance to CO<sub>2</sub> in leaves of Siebold's beech (Fagus crenata) seedlings under elevated ozone.

AbstractText: Ozone is an air pollutant that negatively affects photosynthesis in woody plants. Previous studies suggested that ozone-induced reduction in photosynthetic rates is mainly attributable to a decrease of maximum carboxylation rate (V<sub>cmax</sub>) and/or maximum electron transport rate (J<sub>max</sub>) estimated from response of net photosynthetic rate (A) to intercellular CO<sub>2</sub> concentration (C<sub>i</sub>) (A/C<sub>i</sub> curve) assuming that mesophyll conductance for CO<sub>2</sub> diffusion (g<sub>m</sub>) is infinite. Although it is known that C<sub>i</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub> and J<sub>max</sub> are potentially influenced by g<sub>m</sub>, its contribution to ozone responses in C<sub>i</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub> and J<sub>max</sub> is still unclear. In the present study, therefore, we analysed photosynthetic processes including g<sub>m</sub> in leaves of Siebold's beech (Fagus crenata) seedlings grown under three levels of ozone (charcoal-filtered air or ozone at 1.0- or 1.5-times ambient concentration) for two growing seasons in 2016-2017. Leaf gas exchange and chlorophyll fluorescence were simultaneously measured in July and September of the second growing season. We determined the A, stomatal conductance to water vapor and g<sub>m,</sub> and analysed A/C<sub>i</sub> curve and A/C<sub>c</sub> curve (C<sub>c</sub>: chloroplast CO<sub>2</sub> concentration). We also determined the Rubisco and chlorophyll contents in leaves. In September, ozone significantly decreased C<sub>i</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub>. At the same time, ozone decreased g<sub>m</sub>, whereas there was no significant effect of ozone on C<sub>c</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub> or the contents of Rubisco and chlorophyll in leaves. These results suggest that ozone-induced reduction in C<sub>i</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub> is a result of the decrease in g<sub>m</sub> rather than in carboxylation capacity. The decrease in g<sub>m</sub> by elevated ozone was offset by an increase in C<sub>i</sub>, and C<sub>c</sub> did not differ depending on ozone treatment. Since C<sub>c</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub> was also similar, A was not changed by elevated ozone. We conclude that g<sub>m</sub> is an important factor for reduction in C<sub>i</sub>-based V<sub>cmax</sub> of Siebold's beech under elevated ozone.
